lessons.title: What are Components?
lessons.content:
# Essential to know - Components are reusable UI building blocks. - Function components return JSX. - Component names MUST start with a capital letter. - Can be used like HTML tags ``. --- # What are Components? Components are the **building blocks** of React applications. Think of them as custom, reusable HTML elements. ## Why Components? - **Reusability**: Write once, use everywhere - **Organization**: Break complex UIs into smaller pieces - **Maintainability**: Each component handles one thing ## Function Components The modern way to create components: ```jsx function Welcome() { return

lessons.title: Passing Props
Children Prop
Default Props
lessons.content:
# Essential to know
- Set default values in component parameters.
- Prevents undefined errors.
- Example: `function Btn({ color = 'blue' })`.

---

# Default Props

## Setting Default Values

You can set default values for props when they're not provided.

## Using Default Parameters

```jsx
function Button({ label = "Click me", color = "blue" }) {
  return (
    <button style={{ backgroundColor: color }}>
      {label}
    </button>
  );
}

// Usage
<Button />  // Uses defaults
<Button label="Submit" />  // Custom label, default color
```

## Why Use Defaults?

- **Safer code**: No undefined errors
- **Less boilerplate**: Don't need to pass every prop
- **Self-documenting**: Shows expected values

exercises.title: Using Props
exercises.description: Create a component that uses props.
exercises.instructions:
Create a `Welcome` component that:
1. Accepts a `name` prop
2. Returns: "Hello, {name}!" in an h1
hints: Destructure props in the function parameters: { name }
Use curly braces to embed the name variable in JSX
exercises.validationPrompt: Check if Welcome component accepts a name prop and displays "Hello, {name}!" in an h1

exercises.title: Multiple Props
exercises.description: Work with multiple props and conditional rendering.
exercises.instructions:
Create a `Product` component that:
1. Accepts `name` (string), `price` (number), and `inStock` (boolean) props
2. Displays the name in an h3
3. Displays the price in a paragraph as "$X"
4. If inStock is true, show a green "In Stock" span, otherwise show red "Out of Stock"
hints: Use the ternary operator: condition ? valueIfTrue : valueIfFalse
You can use inline styles with the style prop
exercises.validationPrompt: Check if Product displays name, price with $, and conditionally shows stock status with appropriate colors

exercises.title: Button Component
exercises.instructions:
Create a `Button` component that:
1. Accepts a `label` prop
2. Returns a button element with the label as text
hints: Use curly braces to display the label
exercises.validationPrompt: Check if Button accepts label prop and displays it in a button

exercises.title: Card Container
exercises.description: Create a card that wraps any content.
exercises.instructions:
Create a `Card` component that:
1. Accepts `title` and `children` props
2. Displays title in an h2
3. Renders children below the title
4. Wraps everything in a div
hints: children is a special prop for nested content
Just render {children} where you want the content
exercises.validationPrompt: Check if Card renders title in h2 and children below

exercises.title: Greeting with Default
exercises.instructions:
Create a `Greeting` component that:
1. Accepts name prop with default "Guest"
2. Returns "Hello, {name}!"
hints: Default is used when prop not provided
exercises.validationPrompt: Check if Greeting has default name of Guest
